\chapter{Getting started}
\label{getting_started:getting-started}\label{getting_started::doc}\label{getting_started:welcome-to-renzo-s-documentation}\label{getting_started:id1}
First of all, download \emph{Renzo} latest version using Git

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{cd }your/webroot/folder;
git clone xxxxxxxxxxxx ./;
\end{Verbatim}

Use \href{https://getcomposer.org/doc/00-intro.md\#globally}{Composer} to download dependancies

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
composer install;
\end{Verbatim}

Then copy \emph{conf/config.default.json} file to \emph{conf/config.json}.


\section{Prepare your server}
\label{getting_started:prepare-your-server}
You can either use \emph{Apache} or \emph{Nginx} with Renzo. An example virtual host is provided for each:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
apache.conf

\item {} 
nginx.conf

\end{itemize}

When your virtual host is ready, just go to your website to begin with the setup assistant.


\chapter{Upgrading}
\label{upgrading:upgrading}\label{upgrading::doc}\label{upgrading:id1}
\textbf{Always do a database backup before upgrading.}

Download latest version using \emph{Git}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{cd }your/webroot/folder;
git pull origin master;
\end{Verbatim}

Use \emph{Composer} to update dependancies

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
composer update;
\end{Verbatim}

Then run database schema update

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
bin/renzo schema \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}update;
\end{Verbatim}

If migration summary is OK, perform the changes

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
bin/renzo schema \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}update \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}execute;
bin/renzo cache \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}clear\PYGZhy{}all
\end{Verbatim}


\section{Upgrading Node-types source entities}
\label{upgrading:upgrading-node-types-source-entities}
If some Doctrine errors occur about some fields missing in your \emph{NodesSources},
you must \emph{regenerate all entities} source files

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
bin/renzo core:node:types \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}regenerateAllEntities;
bin/renzo schema \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}update;
\end{Verbatim}

Verify here that no data field will be removed and apply changes

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
bin/renzo schema \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}update \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}execute;
bin/renzo cache \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}clear\PYGZhy{}all
\end{Verbatim}


\chapter{Moving a website to another server}
\label{moving:moving}\label{moving::doc}\label{moving:moving-a-website-to-another-server}
Before moving your website, make sure you have backed up your data:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Dump your database, using \emph{mysql\_dump} or \emph{pg\_dump} tools.

\item {} 
Archive your \emph{/files} folder, it will contain all your documents and font files

\end{itemize}

From this point you can install your new webserver, as described in {\hyperref[getting_started:getting-started]{\emph{Install section}}}.

Then import your dump and files into your new server.

Once you’ve imported your database, you must edit manually your \emph{conf/config.json}, you can reuse the former server’s one and adapt its database credentials. \textbf{Do not perform any schema update now}, it will erase your NodesSources data as their entities files haven’t been generated yet.

When you’ve edited your \emph{conf/config.json} file, regenerate your entities source files

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
bin/renzo core:node:types \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}regenerateAllEntities;
\end{Verbatim}

Now you can perform a schema update without losing your nodes data

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
bin/renzo schema \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}update;
bin/renzo schema \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}update \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}execute;

bin/renzo cache \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}clear\PYGZhy{}all
\end{Verbatim}


\chapter{Creating a theme}
\label{themes/create_theme:create-theme}\label{themes/create_theme::doc}\label{themes/create_theme:creating-a-theme}
First copy \emph{DefaultTheme} folder and rename it against your new theme.
Do not forget to rename every references in:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\textbf{Folder name} and \textbf{Class namespace} must be the same (Ex: “MyAwesomeTheme”) for making autoloader works with your theme.

\item {} 
\textbf{Theme entry point class}: your main theme class must be named after your folder name plus \emph{App} suffix (Ex: “MyAwesomeThemeApp.php”)

\item {} 
\textbf{routes.yml}: rename every route class path using your namespace:

\end{itemize}

\section{Static routing}
\label{themes/create_theme:static-routing}
Before searching for a node’s Url (Dynamic routing), Renzo will parse your theme \emph{route.yml}
to find static controllers and actions to execute.
Static actions just have to comply with the \emph{Request} / \emph{Response} scheme.
It is adviced to add \emph{\$\_locale} and \emph{\$\_route} optional arguments to better handle
multilingual pages.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{foo}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:}
    \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{path}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:}     \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{/foo}
    \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{defaults}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:} \PYG{p+pIndicator}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZus{}controller}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:} \PYG{n+nv}{Themes\PYGZbs{}MyAwesomeTheme\PYGZbs{}Controllers\PYGZbs{}FooBarController}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{fooAction} \PYG{p+pIndicator}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{bar}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:}
    \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{path}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:}     \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{/\PYGZob{}\PYGZus{}locale\PYGZcb{}/bar}
    \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{defaults}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:} \PYG{p+pIndicator}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZus{}controller}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:} \PYG{n+nv}{Themes\PYGZbs{}MyAwesomeTheme\PYGZbs{}Controllers\PYGZbs{}FooBarController}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:}\PYG{n+nv}{barAction} \PYG{p+pIndicator}{\PYGZcb{}}
    \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{requirements}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:}
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Use every 2 letter codes}
        \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{\PYGZus{}locale}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{[a\PYGZhy{}z]\PYGZob{}2\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}
\end{Verbatim}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

        \PYG{n+nx}{Response}\PYG{o}{::}\PYG{n+na}{HTTP\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{k}{array}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}content\PYGZhy{}type\PYGZsq{}} \PYG{o}{=\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}text/html\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{p}{);}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{k}{public} \PYG{k}{function} \PYG{n+nf}{barAction}\PYG{p}{(}

\section{Dynamic routing}
\label{themes/create_theme:dynamic-routing}
\begin{notice}{note}{Note:}
Every node-types will be handled by a specific \emph{Controller}.
If your created a “Page” type, Renzo will search for a \emph{…ControllersPageController} class and
it will try to execute the \emph{indexAction} method.
\end{notice}

An indexAction method must comply with the following signature.
It will take the HttpFoundation’s Request as first then a \emph{Node} and a \emph{Translation} instances.
These two last arguments will be useful to generate your page information and to
render your current node.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{l+s+sd}{/**}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{ * Default action for any Page node.}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{ *}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{ * @param Symfony\PYGZbs{}Component\PYGZbs{}HttpFoundation\PYGZbs{}Request \PYGZdl{}request}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{ * @param RZ\PYGZbs{}Renzo\PYGZbs{}Core\PYGZbs{}Entities\PYGZbs{}Node              \PYGZdl{}node}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{ * @param RZ\PYGZbs{}Renzo\PYGZbs{}Core\PYGZbs{}Entities\PYGZbs{}Translation       \PYGZdl{}translation}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{ *}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{ * @return Symfony\PYGZbs{}Component\PYGZbs{}HttpFoundation\PYGZbs{}Response}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{ */}
\PYG{k}{public} \PYG{k}{function} \PYG{n+nf}{indexAction}\PYG{p}{(}
    \PYG{n+nx}{Request} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}request}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n+nx}{Node} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}node} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k}{null}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n+nx}{Translation} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}translation} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k}{null}
\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}this}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n+na}{prepareThemeAssignation}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}node}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}translation}\PYG{p}{);}

    \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}this}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n+na}{getService}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}stopwatch\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n+na}{start}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}twigRender\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{);}

    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{k}{new} \PYG{n+nx}{Response}\PYG{p}{(}
        \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}this}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n+na}{getTwig}\PYG{p}{()}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n+na}{render}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}types/page.html.twig\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}this}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n+na}{assignation}\PYG{p}{),}
        \PYG{n+nx}{Response}\PYG{o}{::}\PYG{n+na}{HTTP\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{k}{array}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}content\PYGZhy{}type\PYGZsq{}} \PYG{o}{=\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}text/html\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{p}{);}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{Verbatim}

As \emph{Symfony} controllers do, every Renzo controllers actions have to return a valid \emph{Response} object.

Renzo is a polymorphic CMS based on a node system which can handle many type of services.
It’s based on Symfony components and Doctrine ORM for maximum performances and security.
